content.title: Antiplatelet Therapy
content.summary: Antiplatelet agents inhibit platelet activation and aggregation to prevent arterial thrombosis in conditions like coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, and peripheral arterial disease. Major classes include COX-1 inhibitors (aspirin), P2Y12 receptor antagonists (clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor), and GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin plus a P2Y12 inhibitor is standard after ACS and coronary stenting. Key considerations include bleeding risk, drug interactions, and perioperative management.
key_points: Aspirin: irreversible COX-1 inhibition → blocks TXA2 → lasts platelet lifetime (7-10 days)
P2Y12 inhibitors: block ADP receptor → clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor
DAPT: Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor after ACS and coronary stenting
Duration: 6-12 months after stent; 12 months after ACS; may extend if high ischemic risk
Bleeding risk: Assess with PRECISE-DAPT or DAPT scores
Perioperative: Hold clopidogrel 5-7 days; ticagrelor 3-5 days before surgery
content.statement: Antiplatelet therapy uses aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitors to prevent arterial thrombosis, with dual antiplatelet therapy standard after ACS and coronary stenting, balanced against bleeding risk and managed perioperatively with appropriate drug discontinuation intervals.

explanation.intuition: Platelets are the first responders to arterial injury. Aspirin prevents platelets from releasing their 'call to arms' signal (thromboxane A2), while P2Y12 inhibitors block the amplification signal (ADP). Using both creates a stronger anti-clotting effect needed after stents and heart attacks.
explanation.key_insight: Aspirin's effect is irreversible and lasts the platelet's lifetime (~10 days). This means even after stopping aspirin, full platelet function won't return until new platelets are made. In contrast, ticagrelor binds reversibly, so its effect wears off faster (~3-5 days).
explanation.technical_details: Aspirin acetylates COX-1 at Ser530, irreversibly blocking TXA2 synthesis. Clopidogrel and prasugrel are thienopyridine prodrugs requiring hepatic activation (CYP2C19 for clopidogrel). Ticagrelor is a cyclopentyltriazolopyrimidine that directly and reversibly inhibits P2Y12. GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors (abciximab, eptifibatide, tirofiban) block final common pathway of aggregation.

definitions_glossary.antiplatelet_agent: Drug inhibiting platelet activation or aggregation
definitions_glossary.aspirin: Acetylsalicylic acid; irreversible COX-1 inhibitor blocking TXA2 synthesis
definitions_glossary.thromboxane_A2: TXA2; platelet-derived prostaglandin promoting aggregation and vasoconstriction
definitions_glossary.P2Y12_receptor: Platelet ADP receptor; target of clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor
definitions_glossary.prasugrel: Thienopyridine prodrug; more potent P2Y12 inhibitor; contraindicated in prior stroke
definitions_glossary.ticagrelor: Direct-acting reversible P2Y12 inhibitor; twice daily dosing
definitions_glossary.cangrelor: IV P2Y12 inhibitor for procedural use; rapid onset and offset
definitions_glossary.DAPT: Dual antiplatelet therapy; aspirin plus P2Y12 inhibitor
definitions_glossary.GPIIbIIIa_inhibitor: IV agents blocking final pathway of platelet aggregation
definitions_glossary.stent_thrombosis: Thrombotic occlusion of coronary stent; prevented by DAPT
definitions_glossary.CYP2C19: Cytochrome P450 enzyme activating clopidogrel; polymorphisms affect response

aspirin.mechanism: Irreversibly acetylates COX-1; blocks TXA2 synthesis
aspirin.dosing: 75-100 mg daily for prevention; 160-325 mg loading
aspirin.note: Enteric coating delays onset but not used for ACS

clopidogrel.genetic_testing: CYP2C19 poor metabolizers have reduced effect

prasugrel.mechanism: Irreversible; more complete activation than clopidogrel
prasugrel.contraindications: Prior stroke/TIA; age ≥75; weight <60 kg (higher bleeding)

ticagrelor.mechanism: Reversible direct P2Y12 inhibition; no prodrug activation
ticagrelor.maintenance: 90 mg BID (60 mg BID for extended therapy)
ticagrelor.side_effects: Dyspnea, ventricular pauses; avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
ticagrelor.aspirin_dose: Requires low-dose aspirin (81 mg); high-dose reduces efficacy

cangrelor.use: Periprocedural when oral P2Y12 cannot be given

GPIIbIIIa_inhibitors.mechanism: Block GPIIb/IIIa receptor; prevent fibrinogen binding

coronary_artery_disease.ACS_NSTEMI_UA: DAPT: Aspirin + ticagrelor or prasugrel (preferred) or clopidogrel
coronary_artery_disease.STEMI: DAPT: Aspirin + ticagrelor or prasugrel preferred
coronary_artery_disease.stable_CAD: Aspirin monotherapy; DAPT if recent stent
coronary_artery_disease.post_PCI: DAPT duration based on stent type and bleeding risk

cerebrovascular_disease.DAPT_stroke: Short-term DAPT (21-30 days) for minor stroke/high-risk TIA

after_DES.extended: >12 months if high ischemic, low bleeding risk

decision_tools.DAPT_score: Predicts benefit of extended DAPT (ischemic vs bleeding)

elective_surgery.aspirin: Continue if cardiovascular benefit outweighs bleeding

urgent_surgery.platelet_transfusion: May help reverse aspirin; less effective for P2Y12 inhibitors

stent_considerations.minimum_DAPT: Do not stop prematurely after stent
stent_considerations.high_risk_period: First 6 weeks post-DES highest stent thrombosis risk

clopidogrel_resistance.testing: Platelet function testing or CYP2C19 genotyping

definition.@value: Use of agents inhibiting platelet activation and aggregation to prevent arterial thrombosis in cardiovascular disease

scopeNote.@value: Essential after ACS and coronary stenting; includes aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitors

learning_objectives: Compare mechanisms of aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitors
Select appropriate P2Y12 inhibitor based on patient characteristics
Determine DAPT duration based on ischemic and bleeding risk
clinical_pearls: Aspirin is irreversible - effect lasts 7-10 days (platelet lifetime)
Prasugrel contraindicated in prior stroke/TIA - increases bleeding
Ticagrelor requires low-dose aspirin (81 mg) - high dose reduces efficacy
CYP2C19 poor metabolizers have reduced clopidogrel effect
Hold clopidogrel 5-7 days, ticagrelor 3-5 days before surgery
common_misconceptions: All P2Y12 inhibitors are the same - they differ in onset, reversibility, and potency
Aspirin is always continued for surgery - depends on bleeding vs ischemic risk
PPIs always interact with clopidogrel - data is mixed; omeprazole has strongest interaction
